Literature Review: Mitochondrial ion channels play a pivotal role in maintaining cellular homeostasis and regulating various physiological processes. These channels are integral to the function of mitochondria, organelles that are not only the powerhouses of the cell but also key players in signaling, apoptosis, and metabolism. The inner mitochondrial membrane (IMM) is particularly rich in ion channels that regulate the flow of ions such as calcium (Ca2+), potassium (K+), and chloride (Cl-), thereby influencing the mitochondrial membrane potential (ΔΨm) and, consequently, mitochondrial function. This literature review focuses on the biophysical properties, molecular identity, and regulation of mitochondrial ion channels, as well as their potential as therapeutic targets. Calcium channels in mitochondria, such as the mitochondrial calcium uniporter (MCU), are crucial for Ca2+ uptake, which regulates ATP production and cell death pathways. The MCU complex, including its regulatory subunits MICU1 and MICU2, has been extensively studied for its role in modulating Ca2+ influx in response to cellular signals (Baughman et al., 2011; De Stefani et al., 2011). Potassium channels, including the ATP-sensitive K+ (mitoKATP) and the large conductance Ca2+-activated K+ (mitoBKCa) channels, contribute to the regulation of ΔΨm and protect against ischemic damage by modulating mitochondrial volume and ROS production (O'Rourke, 2007; Szewczyk et al., 2009). Chloride channels, such as the mitochondrial chloride intracellular channel (CLIC) proteins, are involved in the regulation of mitochondrial volume and apoptosis (Fernández-Salas et al., 2002). The mitochondrial permeability transition pore (mPTP), often referred to as the mitochondrial megachannel, is a non-selective channel whose opening leads to the collapse of ΔΨm and can trigger apoptosis. The molecular composition of the mPTP has been a subject of debate, with recent studies suggesting a role for the FOF1 ATP synthase in its formation (Giorgio et al., 2013; Bonora et al., 2013). Porin, or the voltage-dependent anion channel (VDAC), located in the outer mitochondrial membrane (OMM), facilitates the exchange of metabolites and ions between the mitochondria and the cytosol and has been implicated in the regulation of apoptosis (Shoshan-Barmatz et al., 2010). The regulation of these channels is complex and involves various factors, including post-translational modifications, interaction with regulatory proteins, and changes in the mitochondrial environment. Given their critical roles in cell physiology and pathology, mitochondrial ion channels have emerged as potential therapeutic targets for a range of diseases, including neurodegenerative disorders, cardiovascular diseases, and cancer. For instance, modulating the activity of mitoKATP channels has been proposed as a strategy to protect against ischemic heart disease (Costa et al., 2006), while inhibitors of the MCU are being explored for their potential to limit cancer cell proliferation (Marchi et al., 2013). In conclusion, mitochondrial ion channels are essential for the regulation of mitochondrial function and cell survival. Understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying their activity and regulation offers promising avenues for the development of novel therapeutic strategies.
